qas.question: Which two companies were involved in the "War of the Speeds"?
Over which years did the "War of the Speeds" last?
Which company lost the "War of the Speeds"?
What speed ultimantly ended up winning the war of the speeds?
By 1945 what was the total sale of 45s?

context: The commercial rivalry between <a0_0>RCA Victor and Columbia Records<a0_0/> led to RCA Victor's introduction of what it had intended to be a competing vinyl format, the 7-inch (175 mm) 45 rpm disc. For a two-year period from <a1_0>1948 to 1950<a1_0/>, record companies and consumers faced uncertainty over which of these formats would ultimately prevail in what was known as the "War of the Speeds". (See also format war.) In 1949 Capitol and Decca adopted the new LP format and <a2_0>RCA<a2_0/> gave in and issued its first LP in January 1950. The <a3_0>45 rpm<a3_0/> size was gaining in popularity, too, and Columbia issued its first 45s in February 1951. By 1954, <a4_0>200 million<a4_0/> 45s had been sold.
